title: C'RIZZ: Absolution. Noun. The remission of sins granted
author: a chosen emancipator of the

elements.text: [Part One]

Absolution. Noun. The remission of sins granted by a chosen emancipator of the Church of the Foundation. An emancipator hand-picked from the Eutermesan masses and rewarded for obedience and total devotion. One governed by the laws of a timeless Universe to which, should he ever leave it, he may never ever return. Out here, amongst these wandering souls, souls who call to me and beg me to join them, out here those laws no longer apply.
Ah, Phelgreth, my dear fellow.
Straith.
How fares our volga herd tonight?
They're not moving. Just standing there. Scared of the fire, I suppose.
Ah yes. That was a capital idea of mine, you know, setting light to the spillage pits. Gave the Outlanders a bit of a shock, eh?
Apart from that, looks like we're in for yet another quiet night. Hold on, what's that?
What's what?
I thought I saw something, sir. At the edge of the barrier. There, look. Look! Looks like it's coming this way. Straith, it's one of those Black Angels!
For the Forsaker's name, it's piercing barrier!
That's impossible. Nothing can penetrate the barrier.
Well, this thing has. Quick, sound the alarm!
Throw me the net. The net!
Alarm bell ringing.
Oh, hang on, it's caught in the
Come on!
Oh, got it. Here.
Right. Angel or no, this should hold you. (effort)
The claws! Phelgreth, don't let it touch you!
(struggling) I'll try to remember that.
You two, help out here.
No you don't. No.
Take it to the crypt. Look lively, guards. Step to it. I'd better tell the Overseer we've captured one. Well done, Sergeant. Text book stuff, eh?
Thank you, sir. I'll see it's secure before, before we begin.
The Black Angel is snarling.
Let's have a look at you then. There, there. Just relax. I'll have some food brought down from the kitchen.
Door opens, footsteps.
Is it secure?
It is.
Pretty looking thing, isn't it? Grey flesh, filthy claws, leathery wings. More beast than man, or woman in this case.
I suppose that makes us more man than beast, then.
Perhaps. Anyway, exciting night. Still, time for me to turn in.
I've got another two hours of patrol ahead. Think I'll ask the cellarer for a mug of hot sherva with a little something extra in it. Might help settle the nerves.
Nerves, Phelgreth? I thought nothing shocked you any more. Well, goodnight.
Night.
Straith leaves. The Black Angel makes noises.
And you should get some sleep as well.
She howls.
[OC]: C'Rizz, come to us. You are our salvation.
Who are you? Why do you need my help?
[OC]: My name is unimportant, my story is not. A long time ago, the people of my world woke one morning to a blinding flash. The planet shook so violently that millions perished
from the tremors alone. They were the lucky ones.
What caused it? A bomb? A meteor?
[OC]: We thought so, until the changes began.
What sort of changes.

[OC]: Many found their bodies distorting and undergoing severe corruption of the tissues, musculature and organs. Their very thought processes were also twisted and warped. Family turned upon family, friend upon friend. The streets ran with blood.
When did all of this happen?
[OC]: I stopped keeping track after the nine hundredth year.
What? You are almost a thousand years old?
[OC]: I stopped counting. Many centuries must have passed since then.
So you're immortal?
[OC]: No, we can die, but things have been slowed.
But why weren't you killed in the bloodshed? How were you not swept up in the chaos and rioting?
[OC]: Simply because it was I who led it. Ah, it is time. I must be gone.
No, wait. Why are you telling me this? What do you want me for?
[OC]: We will meet again very soon.
Knocking on door, door opens.
C'Rizz? Didn't you hear me knocking?
Sorry, Charley. I must have fallen asleep.
Lazybones. May I come in?
Mmm, of course.
What have you been up to? Spring cleaning? What is all this stuff?
Oh, just a few things from home. Here, have a seat.
Do you miss it, home?
Miss it? Not really. There is a feeling, though, as if I'm somehow incomplete.
You're homesick, maybe. It's perfectly normal. I know you were anxious to leave the Divergent Universe, but ultimately it is your home.
Was. This is my home now, the Tardis.
I suppose there are worse places to hang one's hat.
And you and the Doctor, well, you're my (pause) family.
(laughs) What a family. Just don't let me catch you calling me sis, all right?
Of course. So, what has the Doctor been up to?

Oh, let's see. So far he's twice managed to burn out something called a reciprocation circuit, materialised the Tardis on the back of a giant prehistoric turtle, and it was none to pleased about that, I can tell you, and nearly collided with a shiny swirly burgundy blob he kept referring to as the Bertram.
In other words
A typical day in the Tardis.
Anyway, I thought it best to stay out of his way for a while, and I got it into my to have a look in on you. Hope you don't mind me interrupting your tidying.
No, of course not.
Hey, I've never seen you wearing these. What are they?
Ah, those are Thessle beads, made from the sun-bleached knucklebones of Scatterfish.
Fish? I don't remember very much water in the Eutermese Zone.
They live on land. You find them under rocks out in the desert.
Pretty. I think.
Oh, you can wear them if you want.
Er, I think I'll pass, thanks all the same. Knucklebones clash with this frock.
Suit yourself.
Oh, what's this?
Er, nothing. Here
It looks really old.
It is. Could I have it back?
Not until you tell me what it is.
It's called an Absolver.
Oh, I'm sorry. Is it something to do with your Church?
Yes. A religious icon, nothing more.
It's beautiful. What do these inscriptions say?
Oh, just words from our sacred texts.
Buzz.
What did I do? Did I press something? What does this blue light mean?
If you agitate the crystals inside, they (pause) glow, that's all. They're just harmless minerals from my home.
Like your moonstone pendant.
Yes! In some ways. Please, let me put it away now.
No, wait. Let me have a quick look inside.
No, Charley, you mustn't!
Big noise with long drawn out voices.
Knocking.
Straith! Straith, wake up!
What is it, Phelgreth? Some sort of tremor?
I don't think so, sir. Look at the sky. It's, it's opening.
Great Forsaker! Look at the Outlanders, they're retreating, running away in panic.
Is this the prophecy, sir? Sir?
Big rumble.
Charley? Charley, is that you?
[OC]: C'Rizz!
I can't see you, Charley. I can't see anything through this fog. (coughs) What is that awful stench?
[OC]: Come to me, C'Rizz. Help me!
Keep talking, Charley. I can follow your voice.
Something snarls nearby.
What is that? Charley, there's something else in here with us. Be careful! Charley? Charley, I can't hear you any more! Where are you?
(Snarls and multiple voices calling out 'we're trapped, our fate is in your hands or something like it.)
C'Rizz! C'Rizz!
Absolve, all of you, absolve!
Calm down, C'Rizz. It's me. It's Charley.
Charley? I warned you.
About what?
I told you not to open it. The reliquary.
Oh, never mind that. Something's wrong with the Tardis.
The Tardis? I didn't hear anything.
Shh. Listen. Do you hear it? That doesn't sound right to me. We'd better find the Doctor. Come on.
Is it me, or are the lights dimming?
It's not you. It's getting colder, too.
Oh, come on. Let's get to the console room.
Wait. The console room's this way.
Don't be silly. It's this way.
[OC]: Go back.
What was that?
I've no idea, but it's just made the hair on the back of my neck stand up.
Still convinced it's that way?
Er, let's go your way, if it's all the same.
I came as quickly as I could, Lolanthia. The Citadel's in uproar. There's panic everywhere.
They want answers, Overseer. They have convened this meeting because they seek guidance.
And they look to me for it, of course.
Naturally. It is your obligation. You have done it before.
Yes, but never during such troubling times.
You calmed their nerves when those mysterious shapes first appeared in the heavens.
True.
And when long after the disaster, madness seemed to rear its head, you helped unify them and restore order.
That I did.
What are you going to tell them this time, Father?
I don't know. Yet. Let me first pay a visit to the Chapel.
Your people need you, and they need you now.
Don't let's argue, daughter. I shall join you all soon. It's not as though they have something better to do with their time.
Ah, hello. Good of you to finally turn up. You're just in time.
In time for what?
Well, either to witness my masterful skill at saving our lives, or
Or what?
Or to experience the utter destruction of the Tardis. Anyone care to place any bets?
Depends on what the odds are.
Several thousand to one.
In favour of survival or destruction.
Ah, yes.
Doctor, what's happening?
Some sort of psychic interference. The Tardis is confused. It's as if something has scrambled its brains. All the safety buffers are down and we're accelerating out of control through the vortex.
Well, is there anything C'Rizz and I can do?
Yes. Charley, you hold this switch down, and C'Rizz? Stand there, take that lever in your hand, and when I give the word you throw it as if our lives depend on it. Which of course they do.
What are you hoping to do?
I'm going to try and adjust our trajectory to trip the dimensional flow ever so slightly. At the very least it should stabilise our course.
Whenever you're ready, Doctor.
Wait for it, wait for it. Right. Now!
Lever thrown.
Phelgreth, tell me I'm not seeing what I think I'm seeing.
It's the Great Beast, isn't it, sir. Belarus, just as the prophecy foretold. Even from this distance it's huge.
Stay here, Sergeant. I must report this to the Order at once.
The Tardis materialises.
We've stopped.
Can I let go of this?
Yes, of course.
Bong!
The Cloister Bell.
Shall I hold the switch down again?
No, it's nothing to do with you. Let's take a peek outside, shall we?
Scanner on.
Well, we're in non-planetary space, that's for sure. Judging by the stars, I'd say we're somewhere in the constellation of Aries. Yes, that's Triangulum Australe there. and there. Oh dear.
Spaceships.

And lots of them too. That's a Bizarli Pulsecarrier, over there a Ray-R Salutine Sloop, and there a Colith Weaver. Amazing ships, those. They use pre-cognitive technology to fabricate their destination. The resulting paradox of two co-existing zones of identical space and time forces the source sector to cease to be, and the new woven sector, as well as the ship, of course, to instantaneously snap into the resulting hollow. Fascinating.
Impossible.
You'd better not tell that to the Colith, C'Rizz, otherwise their delicately balanced science would crumble, leaving them all stranded in a void of implausibility.
You're talking nonsense again.
Nonsense is to sense as shade is to light. It heightens effect.
Doctor, there must be dozens of ships out there.
Hundreds, I should say.
Well, shouldn't we get out of their way?
They're not moving, C'Rizz. And neither are we. The Tardis doesn't seem to be responding to anything. Curiouser and curiouser. The Cloister Bell's just modulated down by a tri-tone.
I'm assuming that's a bad thing.
Unprecedented. Diabolus in musica.
What is this place? Some kind of spaceship graveyard?
Worse, far worse. I think we're in Limbo, Charley, or Purgatory. Trapped half way between Heaven and Hell.
Banging of gavel.
Order! There will be order in these chambers.

Thank you, Lolanthia. Now I know that you're all concerned about what's been happening. The tremors, the infernal winds, all of it. We know that since the time of the catastrophe, anomalous climactic effects have been commonplace. We have all seen the lights in the sky and heard the thunder. Now admittedly we have never experienced anything quite like this, so what I propose is an extensive period of prayer.
The crowd disagrees.
That is your answer? Prayer? Prayer won't stop showers of ash. Prayer won't halt volcanoes.
Lolanthia, please.
Prayer won't put an end to all this!

If you, if any of you have come here believing that I have all the answers, then you are mistaken. Our fate is, as ever, in the hands of the Forsaker. Remember the words of the prophecy. Thou shalt dwell in Limbo awaiting judgment, for this is thy punishment. Thou shalt endure it in this world of flame until

Please don't start quoting scripture. We all know exactly what is written in your beloved prophecy. You've recited it to us often enough. It doesn't help us walk out of the Citadel, stabilise the weather patterns or heal those shattered souls beyond the walls.
But for now, daughter, right now, it's all that we have. This meeting is adjourned.
Gavel bangs.
Thank you, Father. Superstitious to the last. And so we pray, as the world tumbles down around us.
But Heaven and Hell? I mean, you can't really be serious, Doctor. Can you? What's that on the scanner?
I'm not sure, but I think it may be the reason we're here.
It's like a patch of empty space.
Mmn, definitely not empty. According to these readings, there's something inside it. Listen.
What is that?
Those are non-thermal planetary radio emissions. Many celestial bodies emit them, but I suspect there is something unique about these particular signals. A quick filter adjustment and
That sounds like
People.
The agonised cries of countless lost souls forever imprisoned within a shattered Hell of bleakness and despair.
Hell? Doctor, are you sure you mean

Hell. Tartarus. Hades. Take your pick. Listen, Charley, whatever you call it, every culture, everywhere in the galaxy has some equivalent. Who's to say they didn't all originate in the same place. Here.
But, Doctor, surely
We are in a forbidden sector of space. We must have slipped right past the No
Trespass beacons when the Tardis went out of control. Those beacons are put up for a very good reason, Charley.
Whoomph!
Did you feel that?
We're moving, descending into the anomaly. Hang on, both of you!

Great Forsaker, it is I, Cacothis, your High Priest who calls to you for help. A change has come upon our world. New omens, new augurys. The people look to me for help and yet I am powerless to answer them. Tell me, Great Forsaker, what do these signs portend? Forsaker.
Ahem. Overseer. Sir.
How many times must I say this? I'm not to be disturbed whilst in prayer!
â€˜Yes, sir. Sorry, sir. Won't happen again, sir.
Well, Phelgreth? What can I do for you?
I was asked to update you on the situation outside.
Then pray do so.
We've spotted a shape on the horizon.
A shape? Be more specific, man.
I'm trying, sir.
Indeed you are. Go on.
It's like a ball of smoke, or liquid. Things, faces, forms, swim to the surface as the shape moves. I was wondering whether, well, whether it might be Borarus.
Ah, yes. Borarus the Formist, the Great Beast of Athnagar, the Omega of Time and Space. Well, it certainly sounds like it, doesn't it?
Then it's true, sir? The prophecy, it's coming to pass.
It would appear so, yes. Can it be that after three thousand years we will finally be released?
Sir?
Do you recall how it's supposed to end, the prophecy?
Isn't there something about a pilgrim?

A pilgrim from beyond our world will sacrifice himself to Borarus, filling the beast with such melancholy that it will burst into a shower of crimson tears, never to rise again. Then, and only then, will our torment come to an end. Well, you'd best be getting back to the battlements. See what our Great Beast is up to now, eh?
Yes, sir. What will happen to the Outlanders, sir? Will Borarus destroy them?
Perhaps. It would be a merciful release, would it not?
Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
A merciful release for all of us. I hope the Borarus destroys every living thing in the wastelands. And I hope, I hope Aboresh, that he destroys you too.

Come, my brothers and sisters. It is time. The vessel has been opened, and already the freed souls journey to us across the immensity of space. We must call to them, draw them to the wastelands. Borarus needs such souls to feed upon. And with them we will bring the pilgrim. He alone is the key to our salvation. He will unite with the Beast and crush the Citadel. Victory will be ours. Come, my brethren. Give me your minds and I, Aboresh, will bring this Tardis to us.
Dies irae, irae Faustus. Dies irae, irae Faustus. Dies irae, irae Faustus!
Speed's still increasing. Keep holding on, everyone.
Those voices, I can't bear it, Doctor.
Concentrate, Charley. You should be able to block them out.
I can't. They're inside my head.
What was your favourite nursery rhyme?
What? Er, Oranges and Lemons.
Sing it. Sing it! Come on!
(singing) Oranges and lemons
Say the bells of
Say the bells of Saint Clements. You owe me five farthings say the bells of Saint Martins.
Keep going, Charley. We're nearly through. Any minute now we'll enter the heart of
the anomaly. It's like being in the eye of a hurricane. Things should begin to stabilise.
Peace descends.
There, what did I tell you? Now, let's see if we can ouch!
What's the matter?
The console, it's red hot.
And getting hotter, by the looks of things. The dials and knobs are beginning to melt.
Whumph.
What was that noise?
My God, this is impossible.
Doctor, the floor's cracking!
I don't believe it. The Tardis is splitting apart.
C'Rizz, move!
I, I can't! My legs, I can't move them.
Jump! Jump! Come on, jump, or you'll be sucked into the void.
I can't! Doctor, Charley, argh!
C'Rizz!

Out here, amongst these wandering souls, souls who call to me and beg me to join them, out here those laws no longer apply.
STRAITH: Ah, Phelgreth, my dear fellow.
PHELGRETH: Straith.
STRAITH: How fares our volga herd tonight?
PHELGRETH: They're not moving. Just standing there. Scared of the fire, I suppose.
STRAITH: Ah yes. That was a capital idea of mine, you know, setting light to the spillage pits. Gave the Outlanders a bit of a shock, eh?
PHELGRETH: Apart from that, looks like we're in for yet another quiet night. Hold on, what's that?
STRAITH: What's what?
PHELGRETH: I thought I saw something, sir. At the edge of the barrier. There, look. Look! Looks like it's coming this way. Straith, it's one of those Black Angels!
STRAITH: For the Forsaker's name, it's piercing barrier!
PHELGRETH: That's impossible. Nothing can penetrate the barrier.
STRAITH: Well, this thing has. Quick, sound the alarm!
PHELGRETH: Throw me the net. The net!
STRAITH: Oh, hang on, it's caught in the
PHELGRETH: Come on!
STRAITH: Oh, got it. Here.
PHELGRETH: Right. Angel or no, this should hold you. (effort)
STRAITH: The claws! Phelgreth, don't let it touch you!
PHELGRETH: (struggling) I'll try to remember that.
STRAITH: You two, help out here.
PHELGRETH: No you don't. No.
STRAITH: Take it to the crypt. Look lively, guards. Step to it. I'd better tell the Overseer we've captured one. Well done, Sergeant. Text book stuff, eh?
PHELGRETH: Thank you, sir. I'll see it's secure before, before we begin.
PHELGRETH: Let's have a look at you then. There, there. Just relax. I'll have some food brought down from the kitchen.
STRAITH: Is it secure?
PHELGRETH: It is.
STRAITH: Pretty looking thing, isn't it? Grey flesh, filthy claws, leathery wings. More beast than man, or woman in this case.
PHELGRETH: I suppose that makes us more man than beast, then.
STRAITH: Perhaps. Anyway, exciting night. Still, time for me to turn in.
PHELGRETH: I've got another two hours of patrol ahead. Think I'll ask the cellarer for a mug of hot sherva with a little something extra in it. Might help settle the nerves.
STRAITH: Nerves, Phelgreth? I thought nothing shocked you any more. Well, goodnight.
PHELGRETH: Night.
PHELGRETH: And you should get some sleep as well.

ABORESH: [OC]: Many found their bodies distorting and undergoing severe corruption of the tissues, musculature and organs. Their very thought processes were also twisted and warped. Family turned upon family, friend upon friend. The streets ran with blood.

ABORESH: [OC]: I stopped keeping track after the nine hundredth year.

ABORESH: [OC]: I stopped counting. Many centuries must have passed since then.
C'RIZZ: So you're immortal?
ABORESH: [OC]: No, we can die, but things have been slowed.
C'RIZZ: But why weren't you killed in the bloodshed? How were you not swept up in the chaos and rioting?
ABORESH: [OC]: Simply because it was I who led it. Ah, it is time. I must be gone.
C'RIZZ: No, wait. Why are you telling me this? What do you want me for?
ABORESH: [OC]: We will meet again very soon.

C'RIZZ: Sorry, Charley. I must have fallen asleep.
CHARLEY: Lazybones. May I come in?
C'RIZZ: Mmm, of course.
CHARLEY: What have you been up to? Spring cleaning? What is all this stuff?
C'RIZZ: Oh, just a few things from home. Here, have a seat.
CHARLEY: Do you miss it, home?
C'RIZZ: Miss it? Not really. There is a feeling, though, as if I'm somehow incomplete.
CHARLEY: You're homesick, maybe. It's perfectly normal. I know you were anxious to leave the Divergent Universe, but ultimately it is your home.
C'RIZZ: Was. This is my home now, the Tardis.
CHARLEY: I suppose there are worse places to hang one's hat.
C'RIZZ: And you and the Doctor, well, you're my (pause) family.
CHARLEY: (laughs) What a family. Just don't let me catch you calling me sis, all right?

C'RIZZ: Er, nothing. Here

CHARLEY: Not until you tell me what it is.

CHARLEY: Oh, I'm sorry. Is it something to do with your Church?

C'RIZZ: No, Charley, you mustn't!
PHELGRETH: Straith! Straith, wake up!
STRAITH: What is it, Phelgreth? Some sort of tremor?
PHELGRETH: I don't think so, sir. Look at the sky. It's, it's opening.
STRAITH: Great Forsaker! Look at the Outlanders, they're retreating, running away in panic.
PHELGRETH: Is this the prophecy, sir? Sir?
