C'RIZZ: Strangely pleasant. Shall I release them?
ABORESH: As you wish.
ABORESH: Let's try something a little more complex, shall we?
C'RIZZ: One of the mutants?
ABORESH: I had in mind something bigger. Much bigger. Come on.
DOCTOR: Why have things tumbled backwards, Cacothis? Why have you let them?
CACOTHIS: Because we played God and it was not our place.
DOCTOR: You made a mistake. It happens.
CACOTHIS: Not like this, Doctor. You don't understand.
DOCTOR: Oh, but I do, Cacothis, only too well. You were playing with fire right from the start. Where are the gravitic stabilisers? Where's the breach induction loop? You can't tamper with dimensional engineering without proper safeguards.
CACOTHIS: I know, I know. I argued for more time. I said we weren't ready. But the project was already behind schedule, so
DOCTOR: So you cut corners.
CACOTHIS: Yes.
DOCTOR: I take it this was a military operation?
CACOTHIS: It was funded by the Ministry for Peace, yes.
DOCTOR: A charming euphemism. And what was the thinking behind it? Folding space is a very expensive process. I can't imagine they did it for the furtherance of scientific knowledge.
CACOTHIS: At first it was just to probe other dimensions, to look for minerals and so forth. Then when they saw the possibilities for simultaneous transfer of material from one dimension to another
DOCTOR: They thought not of exploration but of conquest. Instantaneous troop movements into any part of the galaxy. No forewarning, no measured approach. Arrive, kill, conquer.
CACOTHIS: Regardless of their intentions, it all went very wrong. In an attempt to widen the dimensional breach, I bombarded the projectors with ionised taxonin. The relays exploded, the breach sheared through our world, and I was ripped in two.
DOCTOR: You heal well.
CACOTHIS: I use the expression very precisely, Doctor. The breach literally bisected my body. As I lay there on the laboratory floor, watching my life blood drain from me, I witnessed something beyond belief. Something miraculous.
DOCTOR: Go on.
CACOTHIS: From my shattered torso, a new lower half emerged. New bones, new tissues, new everything. Since then, I have not aged a day. Neither has anyone in the Citadel. No death, no new life.
DOCTOR: How long has it been like this, Cacothis?
CACOTHIS: Many lifetimes. Can you even begin to fathom what it must be like to live for thousands of years, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I can begin to.
CACOTHIS: Everything is as it was on the day the world ended. None of us can die or change. Children are an impossibility. Everything resets, nothing evolves. Our God was science, and science became angry and betrayed us all.
DOCTOR: So the faithless became the faithful. But not all.
CACOTHIS: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: Someone among your ranks has not put away their faith in technology.
CACOTHIS: That cannot be. To enter these chambers is forbidden. The penalty is
DOCTOR: Yes? What sort of punishment can one issue to an immortal? I imagine execution can become quite dull after the third or fourth time.
DOCTOR: Shh.
CACOTHIS: Your young companion, Miss Charley?
DOCTOR: I don't think so. She should still be asleep upstairs.
CACOTHIS: Well, who then?
DOCTOR: Perhaps the other sinner in your midst, Cacothis. Come on.
STRAITH: Phelgreth? Phelgreth.
PHELGRETH: Sir.
STRAITH: Gather the guard. I want every man and woman who's ever patrolled this roof top to report to me immediately.
PHELGRETH: Sir.
STRAITH: These Outlanders are up to something, and I don't like it, not one jot. Well, what are you waiting for, man?
PHELGRETH: Sorry, sir, it's just er, shouldn't we be worrying about Borarus? The beast is nearly at the barrier.
STRAITH: Try and see the bigger picture, Phelgreth. Just because Borarus is the largest thing on the horizon doesn't make it the most important. It's the Outlanders we should be worrying about, you mark my words. Well, get a move on!
PHELGRETH: Of course, sir. Sorry, sir.
COMPUTER: Computer array to level ten, external monitors online.
LOLANTHIA: Log entry two thousand forty one. Sorry, two, I think. Anyway, today I'm going to bring the array back online to try
CACOTHIS: Lolanthia, how could you? This is blasphemy.
LOLANTHIA: Father! What are you doing here?
CACOTHIS: You have betrayed our sacred doctrine.
LOLANTHIA: Your doctrine, Father, not mine.
CACOTHIS: Don't you know the penalty? How could you do this?
LOLANTHIA: Because we made this world and it is our responsibility to unmake it.
DOCTOR: If I could just
CACOTHIS: Stay out of this, Doctor.
LOLANTHIA: No, Father. Let him speak. This isn't just some petty family matter. The Doctor may have the answer.
DOCTOR: Actually, it's more of a question. What in the name of Kasterborous is that?
CACOTHIS: It is Borarus, the Formless. The prophecy foretells its arrival at the time of the Wasting. A pilgrim
LOLANTHIA: Impressive though it appears, Doctor, it's nothing more than an unusual phenomenon. An energy amoeba. The barrier will stop it, don't worry.
DOCTOR: I hope you're right, Lolanthia. I really do.
PHELGRETH: Straith, what do we do?
STRAITH: I have already told you, Phelgreth. Borarus is not a threat. The barrier will hold it.
PHELGRETH: You're certain of that?
STRAITH: I'll stake my reputation on it.
STRAITH: I don't believe it. It's coming through! Sound the alarm, you fool!
LOLANTHIA: It's breached the barrier. How is that possible? Father?
CACOTHIS: When Borarus comes into the Citadel, then must all sinners repent, for it is the Time of Shriving.
DOCTOR: You won't get any sense out of him. Now, what powers this so-called impenetrable barrier?
LOLANTHIA: I've no idea. Presumably there are residuals still left in the power banks.
DOCTOR: Possibly. What ever it is, we need to boost that power ten-fold, and we need to do it now.
LOLANTHIA: Yes, Doctor. Main generators coming online.
STRAITH: Overseer, forgive the intrusion but
CACOTHIS: Straith, I want you and your men to arrest these two.
STRAITH: Arrest them? But the creature, Borarus, it's breached
CACOTHIS: That is an order. Take these blasphemers to the Chapel and lock them inside.
DOCTOR: Don't be a fool, Cacothis. With any luck, we should be able to stop this.
CACOTHIS: Remove them from my sight, Straith! At once!
DOCTOR: You're making a big mistake, Cacothis.
LOLANTHIA: Father, we need to put things right. Father!
CACOTHIS: Oh, and Straith?
STRAITH: Overseer?
CACOTHIS: Find that girl Charley. See that she is reunited with the Doctor.
STRAITH: Yes, sir.
COMPUTER: Projector array to level zero.
CACOTHIS: Aurithca, our daughter has failed us.
DOCTOR: Straith, listen to me. You have to let us reactivate the barrier. The lives of everyone in this Citadel depend on it.
STRAITH: Sorry, Doctor. It's more than my job's worth.
LOLANTHIA: Hear that, Straith? Borarus is tearing the Citadel apart.
STRAITH: Then the sooner I take care of you, Miss, the sooner me and my men can return to the fight.
DOCTOR: The battle plan's all in order, then? Attacking on the right flank with flaming arrows? Whatever you have in mind, it won't work. You're dealing with something totally alien to your planet.
STRAITH: We'll do our best, won't we, men.
MEN: Yes, sir.
STRAITH: Now move!
STRAITH: C'RIZZ [OC]: Let them go.
STRAITH: Who is it? Show yourself!
STRAITH: C'RIZZ [OC]: Release them. Now.
LOLANTHIA: That voice. Is it Borarus?
DOCTOR: No, it's C'Rizz. I've no idea how you're managing this, C'Rizz, but I certainly am glad to hear your voice.
LOLANTHIA: What is this C'Rizz?
DOCTOR: He's my own personal deus ex machina.
STRAITH: (scared) I'm not afraid of ghostly voices.
STRAITH: C'RIZZ [OC]: I'm not going to ask again. Let them go!
STRAITH: C'RIZZ [OC]: I did warn you.
DOCTOR: What are you doing to him, C'Rizz?
DOCTOR: C'RIZZ [OC]: He must know agony, Doctor. First he must confess his sins, and then he must pay for them. Only then can he be absolved. Confession! Penance! Absolution!

elements.text: [Part Four]
C'RIZZ [OC]: Charley. Charley, help me.
C'Rizz, is that you? Where are you? C'RIZZ [OC]: Everywhere. Nowhere. I'm afraid.
Don't be. I'm here. I'll always be here.
C'RIZZ [OC]: I, I can't control it any more.
Control what? C'RIZZ [OC]: Confession. Penance. Absolution.
That's enough, C'Rizz. Let them go. We are free.
C'RIZZ [OC]: Doctor, I can't stop it. Help me!
Quickly, Doctor. They're dying.
: C'Rizz, withdraw now.
C'RIZZ [OC]: Sorry, Doctor. I'm losing control.
Control of what?
C'RIZZ [OC]: The creature, Borarus, but it's too much for my mind. He said I could handle it and he was wrong.
Who did? C'Rizz, you're not making sense.
C'RIZZ [OC]: Must go, Doctor.
Silence.
C'Rizz? C'Rizz! Right, time for some answers. Lolanthia, fetch your father and meet me in the crypt.
The crypt?
Just do it. I need to find Charley.
Runs off.
You're doing fine, C'Rizz.
Aboresh, I feel as though I'm losing control of the creature. I nearly killed those guards.
I do not believe you'd have let them die. You are strong, C'Rizz. Stronger than any who have gone before you. The barrier around the Citadel has been breached. That has only happened once before.
And when was that?
A long time ago. Now Borarus is upon their walls and our army
Your army.
My army surges in support. The Citadel will fall.
What then?
Punishment for the sinners who dwell within.
You're holding something back, Aboresh. If you want me to help you, I need to know everything.
They, they took her prisoner.
A girl? All this for a girl?
Door opens, footsteps.
The man called himself Aboresh.
Oh, really. I do wish you'd tell me these things. Secrets are all very well when the universe isn't at stake.
Well, how was I to know it was important?
Ah, Cacothis. We meet again.
What is this about, Doctor?
Snarl.
So, you're the creature that made it through the barrier. Hello, I'm the Doctor.
I wouldn't stand so near to the creature, Doctor. It bites.
Pleased to see you again, Charley.
And you, Lolanthia.
Right, shall we get started?
Uses the bioscanner.
Where did you find that device, Doctor?
The bioscanner? Oh, down in your laboratory, along with all those other abandoned fragments of yesteryear.
What are you doing?
Collecting samples and confirming a theory.
And what theory would that be?
Inversion barriers tend to work by preventing genetically different material from passing through them, whilst at the same time allowing right of entry to species with the same genetic code.
What is it? What's the readout?
As i suspected. Lolanthia, I wonder if you'd mind standing still for a moment.
Why are you scanning me?
Just a minute. Cacothis, how long has this creature been imprisoned here?
Er, two thousand years, perhaps.
A near-perfect genetic match. Take a look at the readings, Lolanthia.
No. No!
What is it?
We, we have the same DNA.
But that's impossible, unless
Mother?
You never did say what happened to your wife, Cacothis.
No. No, Doctor, it cannot be!

For two millennia, your wife has been chained up like an animal, and for what crime. Being different? Being from the outside? And all it would have taken for you to know the truth would have been a simple scan using equipment that you yourself outlawed.
But the creature was mad! She was. That is not Aurithca. No! I won't believe it!
Cacothis, come back! Stay with Lolanthia, Charley, and unchain that poor creature.
Runs.
Borarus roars.
Straith, what did the Overseer say?
That is for me to know and you to find out. Now report!
None of our weapons are having the slightest effect on it. We have no defence against that creature.
What about the lasers?
Lasers? The law forbids them.
Oblivion with the law. I've just been throttled half to death by a phantom! Now, I want a bank of bararic lasers along that wall, and I want it now. Go on, move it!
Right. Men, you heard him.
Sir.
I hope you know what you're doing.
So do I, Phelgreth. So do I.
Cacothis, what is this place?
It's the Chapel, a place of introspection.
Why did you run?
Oh, shame, guilt.
So you survived the inversion unscathed and she didn't. You can't help that.
Would that it were only that.
Then what is it?

There was a young scientist. Handsome, clever, charming. Everyone adored him. The design of the gyroscopic core was his, and it was a work of genius. When preparations for the great day neared, I focused all my time and energy on the work. Aurithca felt, oh, lonely, I suppose. Excluded.
She left you for this other man.
I confronted her about it. Some terrible things were said and we separated.
Did Lolanthia know?

No. Not then, not now. Neither did the lover. I never confronted him about the affair. I simply sacked him. However, without his genius, the project was doomed to failure. So you see, Doctor, I let my vanity destroy this world.
The Black Angel mews.
Two thousand years, Mother, chained up, locked away, hidden from me. I've missed you. What kind of world is this, Charley? This, this is my mother and look what we've done to her!
She's free now, Lolanthia. Your mother's free.
Come, Charley. I need to get back to the laboratory.
The Doctor told us to wait here.
No, he told you to stay with me, so accompany me to the laboratory. If I can
reverse the rotation of the gyroscopes, I might be able to weaken the barrier, perhaps even destroy it.
Why would you want to do that? Surely it's the only protection you've got against the Outlanders.
Who do you think the Outlanders are, Charley? They're us. Our families. People like my mother here. Come on, before it's too late.
I'm right behind you.
Put your back into it, men. And fire!
The beams are passing right through the creature, Straith.
I can see that, Phelgreth. Once more! Fire!
What are they doing? I did not authorise the use of technology.
Don't worry, those lasers won't harm Borarus. We're dealing with an entity composed of memory and thought.
So how do we defeat it?
I still have an ace up my sleeve.
And that is?
C'Rizz, my friend, out in the Wastelands. I need to communicate with him.
And how do you propose to do that?
Ancient Gallifreyan technique. Go outside and shout. This way.
(distant) C'Rizz!
Aboresh, it's the Doctor.
Tell him to leave.
I'll try, but I promise you he won't budge.
Why not?
Because he's the Doctor, that's why.
C'Rizz!
Whoosh.
I'm here, Doctor.
A phantom.
A Eutermesan.
Doctor, you must leave this place, and me. Please.
Not until you explain to me what is happening here.
I can't, Doctor. You'll just have to trust me.
Whoosh.
No, no, wait. C'Rizz! Don't just fade away.
He wouldn't listen.
Then we must proceed without him. We stand on the verge of total victory, C'Rizz. We cannot turn back now. Behold the thousands of dispossessed souls you have already brought me here.
What do you mean, that I have brought here?
You brought them across the immensity of space and time, and delivered them here. Together we will destroy the Citadel.
I cannot allow that.
You cannot stop it.
Doctor, Lolanthia's attempting to destroy the barrier.
Is she now? That'll certainly irritate our giant amoeba up there.
Should we stop her?
Anything that irritates Borarus is fine by me.
Doctor, what's Borarus?
Borarus is legion, Charley. A pseudo-physical gestalt of the psychic emanations you released from C'Rizz's Absolver.
Oh, so, so this is all my fault then.
Condemn the fault and not the actor of it.
What?

Measure For Measure, Act Two, Scene Two. What I mean is, you're not to blame for those souls being in the Absolver in the first place. You released them by accident. Terrible things happen by accident, but great things too. I met you by accident.
Roar, crash!
Doctor, Borarus is breaking through.
Unless that creature is stopped, it will consume this world, the next, and quite possibly the universe itself.
But how do we stop it, Doctor?
We can't.
Borarus roars.
Absolution is what you do best, C'Rizz. Don't turn from it.
I, I did not mean for this to happen.
On your homeworld you thought only of there and then, absolving those without future. Absolving everyone, in fact.
They had to be saved.
Saved from you. No one touched by your hand was ever saved. All who feel the sting of your blade are damned.
Absolved!
Damned. Hear their cries, C'Rizz.
Borarus roars.
They call out from the endless night. They call for release. And you can save them all.
How? How do I do it?
Be true to yourself. Suit your form to your deeds.
Squidge, squelch.
What's happening? It's not supposed to work like this. Ah, it hurts! Help me, Aboresh. I don't want to die.
You're not dying, C'Rizz. You're evolving. Brothers and sisters, the way is open! Follow me to the Citadel! Paradise awaits!
It sounds like the Outlanders have broken through, Doctor. We'd better barricade this door somehow.
Get away, Charley. Get away from there!
Big crash!
Why couldn't they knock like anyone else?
Ah, Charley, we meet again. Come here, girl.
Let go of her, Aboresh.

I think I'll hold onto her for the time being, in case you're feeling heroic, Doctor. Silence, rabble. I got you what you wanted. Access to the Citadel. Now go off and enjoy it! What happens here is none of your concern. Oh, peace at last.
You must be C'Rizz's new best friend.
I am his mentor.
And just what have you been teaching him?
I've been helping him to realise his full potential. Someone had to correct the damage done by your interference.
Interference?
You took him out of his home universe. Within the confines of that dimension, C'Rizz was on his way to becoming a god.
A god?
Sounds most unhealthy.
Silence!
Aboresh! You are not welcome here.
I'm not leaving without her, Cacothis.
I don't know who you mean.
Oh, don't play the fool. You know I'm talking about Aurithca. Her mother, your wife, my beloved.
Father, what does he mean?
Oh, how touching. You never told her? Wanted to spare her heartache, did you?
I would have told her, but, but after the accident there was no point.
There was no accident.
Ah, now we come to the interesting part. Go on, Aboresh.

I knew back then that my days were numbered in the facility. I was too intelligent for my own good. Well, the last thing I wanted was to see Cacothis getting all the credit for the probe's success, so when he fired me.
You sabotaged the machinery.
Before I left, I shorted out the projector's rod cluster.
Then it's you who are to blame for all this. For everything!
Yes, but I have learned to live with that.
You murderer!
Cacothis, don't!
Cacothis screams.
Ah, ah, ah. You forget the powers now under my command. I can tear you limb from limb simply by force of will.
Argh, no, please no. The pain! It's like, like daggers in my mind.
Leave him alone!
No, girl. I have waited eons for this moment. How does it feel, Cacothis?
No! No! No! No, I won't beg.
(sotto) Doctor, we've got to help him.
(sotto) Lolanthia, push the turbine up to maximum
(sotto) What will that do?
(sotto) Just do it. I can manipulate the resonance, and may be able to set up a telepathic interference pattern.
(sotto) Maximum output, Doctor.
(sotto) All right. Apologies for the headaches.
But I don't have a headache.
Now!
Very short big noise. Cries of pain.
Cacothis, pull the red lever.
What, Doctor?

The red lever next to you. It opens the central air shaft. Look at Aboresh. He's standing directly over the hatchway. He'll be sucked half a kilometre underground. Charley, help him. I can't hold these turbines much longer. They're going to burn out.
(laughs) Did you think gravity would stop me, Doctor? Levitation is but child's play to a mind as powerful as mine.
You, you have destroyed everything!
Father, no!
You will die, Cacothis. Die!
Oh, what have you done? I wronged you. I am so sorry.
Witness my apotheosis, Aurithca. Soon we will be united, my love. You and I for eternity.
Aurithca shrieks and flaps her wings.
Aurithca, what are you doing? No! No!
His cries fade out to a distant splat.
Close the hatch, Charley.
Right.
Creak, clang.
That's it.
Lolanthia cries.
Your mother saved us, Lolanthia. The least we can do is repay the compliment and save your world. This isn't over yet.
Straith! We must withdraw to the armoury.
What does it look like I'm trying to do.
Straith, look out!
A snarling something attacks. Phelgreth dispatches it.
Straith, give me your arm. I can carry you.
No. No, I, I'm done. This is the Forsaker's will. I leave the defence of the Citadel to you. Carry on, Captain Phelgreth.
You stupid old man. How am I supposed to do all this on my own? Come on, if you're coming.
Borarus attacks, Phelgreth's scream fades into the distance.
Sonic screwdriver, then door closes.
It's done, Lolanthia. But only use it as a last resort.
I understand, Doctor.
Good. Charley, it's time we went up top again.
C'Rizz?
C'Rizz. He may yet be able to salvage this situation.
Good luck, Doctor, and goodbye.
Goodbye for now. We're hoping to come back in one piece, aren't we, Doctor?
Absolutely, for a nice cup of sherva and a slice of cake. Au revoir. Remember, Lolanthia, don't throw that switch unless all hope is lost. You promise?
I promise.
Ta ta for now.
Footsteps up stairs.
As far as I'm concerned, Doctor, all hope is already lost.
Hum of machinery powering up.
What was that thing you built for Lolanthia?

A genetic assimilator. I realigned the projector core to fold not space and time, but genes. If she activates it, it'll merge the genes of the Outlanders with those of anyone left in the Citadel. Stop.
Roar! Scream!
Is that a good thing?
Not if you and I are still in the Citadel. Our genes would go into the melting pot too.
Well, let's hope she doesn't throw the switch.
I'd be very much surprised if she hasn't already.
What?
Don't worry, I built in a five minute delay.
Five minutes? Well what are we hanging around here gassing for? Come on!
Oh, we made it. The Tardis.
Back to its old blue self.
(Crash!
Oh, look out! Borarus.
Borarus, halt.
C'Rizz! Is that you? What's happened to you? You look like the Devil.
C'Rizz clops forward on hooves. His voice is deeper, angry, and reverberates slightly.
I am as I should be. This is my true form.

C'Rizz, listen to me. You need to recapture those souls and put them back into your Absolver, otherwise your pet Borarus here is going to absorb every populated planet in this corner of the galaxy, and then once it's done it'll move on to other galaxies until it absorbs every living thing in this universe.
You need not fear the Beast. It is but an extension of myself.
C'Rizz, what's happened to you? What have they done to you?
And as for the Absolver, it is worthless now. It has served its purpose. It was only ever an elaborate key to unlock a far greater vessel. You see, the actual Absolver is me.
What?
Is this what you were constructed for, C'Rizz?
What do you mean, constructed? This is C'Rizz we're talking about. Flesh and blood, remember?
Flesh and blood maybe, Charley, but I think his people somehow built him for a purpose. Maybe he's a living Reliquary. Is that it, C'Rizz?
You show some understanding of my purpose, Doctor.
You're both talking nonsense. This is C'Rizz, not some, I don't know, machine.

Maybe the Eutermesans wanted immortality, Charley, but weren't quite clever enough to achieve it. Instead they created a vessel which would contain their thoughts and essences beyond death, preserving them in the hope that future generations would solve the
problem of eternal life. I think C'Rizz is that vessel.
The souls that make up Borarus, they were never inside the Reliquary. They were always within me.
Then reclaim them, C'Rizz.
I'm sorry, Doctor, I can't do that. Borarus is destiny.
Yours or ours?
I must save you both!
Save us for what? Absorption, absolution, whatever you call it, that's not salvation. That's murder.
I am not an angel of death, Doctor, but an angel of life everlasting.
C'Rizz, listen to me. If you continue with this madness, the last two people who love you will be gone forever.
No. You will be saved, preserved.
No, C'Rizz, that's nonsense.
Your essences will be contained within me forever.
All right, C'Rizz, all right. Absolve me if you must, but let Charley go. Let her go.
Doctor, no!
I have no choice.
Yes, you do. Nobody controls you. You are the master of your own destiny.
Big rumble.
(sotto) Was that your assimilator thing?
(sotto) The five minutes are up.
C'Rizz, do something or we'll all die. Please!
What have you done?
Too late, Charley. I'm sorry.
All cry out! Rumble which then reverses itself into silence.
What's happened? Did it go wrong?
It can't have gone wrong. The process was irreversible.
Oh, Doctor, look at C'Rizz. He's back to normal!
C'Rizz? Was this your doing?
(in pain) I absorbed it, Doctor. The power of the genetic assimilator.
That's madness. It'll break down your genome.

I know. It was the only way of saving you. Aboresh was wrong about you, Doctor. He said that you interfered in my development, held me back. Argh! But you showed me how a person may become something greater than himself, may fashion his own destiny. And you brought me the gift of Time. It helped heal many wounds, Doctor, except one.
L'Da.
I miss her so much, Doctor.
I know.
Ah! (gasps) I'll shortly be joining her.
(crying) No, C'Rizz, you can't die.
I've been running from my own salvation for far too long, Charley. It'll be good to face it. Finally.
Moaning voices, briefly.
Borarus and I, we're finished. It won't be long now. Journey's end.
No, C'Rizz. There's more to see, more of the universe to explore. Tell him, Doctor. We can make it all right. We can fix it.
It's too late, Charley.
No, it can't be. We can't let him die.
I'm not scared of dying, Charley. All things must die. (roar that fades out) Borarus is no more, and I've only a little time left to say goodbye. Farewell, Doctor. Thank you for everything.
Goodbye, C'Rizz.
Argh!
Oh, C'Rizz.
No more words, sis, except these two. Goodbye, Charley.
Fizz like a Catherine Wheel spinning and ending.
He, he's gone.
I know, I know.
Thunder.
Doctor, is that sunshine?
After three thousand years. C'Rizz's final gift. Come on, let's get back to the Tardis before we get soaked through.
You all right, Charley?
The Tardis seems to have repaired itself.
Yeah, everything's back to the way it was before.
Before what?
Time and place, Charley. Come on. Where to next? How about a spot of Commedia dell'Arte to cheer you up? Harlequin, Columbina. Of course, my favourite's always been II Dottore.
How can you be like this?
What?
Doctor, C'Rizz is dead. He just turned to dust in front of us, and look at you, all smiles and where to next, Charley.
I'm sorry.
Sorry? Just now you said, back to the way it was before. You meant before C'Rizz, didn't you? It's almost as if you're glad. Glad he's gone. Is that it?
Charley, I don't know what to say to you. I know what's happened is painful for you.
Painful for me? What about you?
I
You never really cared for him, did you, Doctor. Well? Oh, come on, admit it.
Charley, that's just not true.

Isn't it? Look at yourself. You're perfectly happy to just, I don't know, to carry on as if nothing has happened. How can you do that? Oh, it's because you liked it the way it used to be, before the Divergent Universe. Just you and naive little Charlotte Pollard hanging on your every word.
Charley, Charley, stop it.
